page.title: 02FRUIT GROWING NEAR CANTERB'Y
page.content: Much of the land immediately east of Canterbury is important for fruit growing. The area has deep, well-drained loamy soils mainly derived from brickearth. The climate is ideal with low annual rainfall(600- 625mm per annum), favourable summer temperatures(18C in July), adequate sunshine and freedom from damaging frosts. Another factor is the excellent communications -A2/M2 which links London to the continent. The main top fruits of the area surveyed are dessert apples, plums and cherries. The dominant apple variety variety is Cox's Orange Pippin with some Worcester Permain. The two main pear varieties are Conference and Doyenne du Camice. There are also some cherries and Victoria plums grown.
